questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is associated with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation: Rheumatoid arthritis is associated with HLA DR4.

questions.question: Question 2: Which part of the spine is most commonly affected in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
The atlantoaxial joint (C1 & C2) is the most commonly affected part of the spine in patients 
with rheumatoid arthritis. The joints in rheumatoid arthritis are bilaterally and symmetrically involved. The commonly 
affected joints are: • Metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints • Wrists • Proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints • Metatarsophalangeal joints (MTP) joints • Atlantoaxial joint There is relative sparing of the DIP joint in rheumatoid arthritis. The involvement of DIP joints 
should direct suspicion towards osteoarthritis.

questions.question:
Question 3: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her 
hands. 558 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive 
of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis. Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal 
interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively.

questions.question:
Question 4: A patient presents to your clinic with the following deformity. In which of the following 
conditions is this deformity seen?
questions.explanation:
The given image shows a swan-neck deformity seen in a patient with established rheumatoid 
arthritis(RA). Swan-neck deformity is hyperextension at the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint 
and flexion at the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Some of the other small joint deformities of the hand in a patient with RA include: 565 
Sold by @itachibot Boutonnie■re deformity with flexion at the PIP joint and hyperextension at the DIP joint. Z-line deformity with hyperextension at the DIP joint and subluxation of the 1st 
metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint.

questions.question:
Question 5: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with 
stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient’s hands is given 
below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 559 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The above image shows flexion at the PIP joint and extension in the DIP joints which is known as 
boutonniere deformity which is seen in rheumatoid arthritis(RA). If the patient gives a history of pain/stiffness in the joints in the early hours of the day which 
usually decreases as the day progresses suggesting inflammatory arthritis and if it presents with 
predominant involvement of smaller joints, it is most likely a case of RA(option A). It occurs due to the accumulation of inflammatory mediators which on increased joint mobility 
are flushed out due to increased blood supply. Pain and stiffness in osteoarthritis (Option B) usually increase as the day progresses due to an 
increase in the activity of the joint. They typically present with nodules around the distal 
interphalangeal joint (Heberden nodes) and proximal interphalangeal joint (Bouchard nodes).

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
The most common extra-articular manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis(RA) is subcutaneous 
nodules. The nodules are generally benign, non-tender, and firm, and occur in areas subjected to repeated 
trauma such as the forearm, sacral prominences, and Achilles tendon. They can also occur in the 
lungs, pleura, pericardium, and peritoneum. Patients who have a history of cigarette smoking had early onset arthritic manifestations and 
tested positive for RA factor or ACPA are more likely to develop extra-articular manifestations. 
Other common extra-articular manifestations include secondary Sjogren's syndrome, interstitial 
lung disease, pulmonary nodules, and anemia. FELTY’S syndrome is a triad of neutropenia, 
splenomegaly, and nodular RA.

questions.question: Question 7: Which is the most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
The most common cardiac valvular lesion seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is mitral 
regurgitation.

questions.question:
Question 8: Which of the following would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with Felty 
syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Hepatomegaly is not seen in Felty syndrome. 566 
Sold by @itachibot Felty syndrome is defined by the clinical triad of: • Neutropenia • Splenomegaly • Rheumatoid arthritis It occurs in the late stages of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Other syndromes associated with rheumatoid arthritis are: • Caplan’s syndrome- characterized by both rheumatoid arthritis and pneumoconiosis. It is 
associated with development of multiple peripheral basilar nodules in the lungs. • Secondary Sjogren’s syndrome- development of keratoconjunctivitis sicca or xerostomia in 
association with connective tissue disorder.

questions.question: Question 9: Which is the most common type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
The most common histopathologic type of lymphoma seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is 
diffuse large B cell lymphoma (DLBCL). The risk of developing lymphoma increases if the patient has Felty’s syndrome or high levels of 
disease activity.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient complains about difficulty doing chores due to morning stiffness of the joints. 
Investigations show elevated ESR, CRP, and positive Rheumatoid factor. Which of the 
following is not likely to be seen in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis, which is associated with 
hypoandrogenism. It is characterized by low levels of serum testosterone, LH, and DHEA. The conditions associated with rheumatoid arthritis are: • Cardiovascular disease, congestive heart failure • Osteoporosis - hip fractures are more likely to occur • Ocular - keratoconjunctivitis sicca, episcleritis, scleritis, keratitis • Secondary Sjogren's syndrome • Hypoandrogenism in men and postmenopausal women

questions.question:
Question 11: All of the following characteristics are found in the pleural effusion fluid of a rheumatoid 
arthritis patient except:
questions.explanation:
Low glucose (<60 mg/dL) is seen in the pleural effusion fluid of a patient with rheumatoid 
arthritis (RA). RA causes exudative pleural effusion and fulfills the Light’s criteria. High LDH and RA factor are 
found in the pleural fluid of RA patients. Less commonly, patients with RA may have a cholesterol 567 
Sold by @itachibot effusion. It is sterile and has a milky or opaque appearance. The milky appearance is due to the 
presence of cholesterol crystals and an elevated cholesterol level. Light’s criteria is used to distinguish between exudative and transudative pleural effusions. An 
exudative pleural effusion satisfies at least one of the following criteria: • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein > 0.5 • Pleural fluid LDH / serum LDH > 0.6 • Pleural fluid LDH more than 2/3rds upper limit of normal for serum

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following radiological features would help to differentiate between rheumatoid 
arthritis and SLE?
questions.explanation:
Articular erosions on X-ray is seen in rheumatoid arthritis (RA), but not in SLE. Juxta-articular osteoporosis, swelling of PIP joint, and ulnar deviation can be seen in both SLE 
and RA. Jaccoud arthropathy is a deforming non-erosive arthropathy characterized by the ulnar deviation 
of the second to 5th fingers with metacarpophalangeal joint subluxation seen in SLE. The give X-ray shows Jaccoud's arthropathy: 568

questions.question: Question 13: What is the most common cause of death in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation: The most common cause of death in patients with rheumatoid arthritis is cardiovascular disease.

questions.question:
Question 14: In a suspected case of rheumatoid arthritis, which of the following markers should be used to 
diagnose this condition?
questions.explanation:
The most appropriate marker to diagnose rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is the anti-CCP (cyclic 
citrullinated peptide) antibody as it is the most specific marker for RA. Anti-CCP, ESR, and CRP values correlate with the disease activity. 569 
Sold by @itachibot Rheumatoid factor can occur in other autoimmune diseases as well as in chronic infections. 
Therefore it is not considered specific.

questions.question:
Question 15: Which of the following is the drug of choice for the treatment of a patient with rheumatoid 
arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Methotrexate which is a DMARD is the drug of choice for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis 
(RA). A combination regimen is used when there is a failure to achieve adequate improvement with 
methotrexate only. Methotrexate in low doses causes adenosine release and suppresses joint inflammation. However, 
in high doses, it causes inhibition of dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).

questions.question:
Question 16: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose 
corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would 
be your recommendation for the further management of this patient?

options.a: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.explanation:
For further management of a patient with rheumatoid arthritis (RA) with worsening disease 
activity, the preferred therapy is a step-up to oral triple therapy with methotrexate, sulfasalazine, 
and hydroxychloroquine. The addition of leflunomide or a biological (anti - TNF) to methotrexate 
is another alternative. Ideally, the approach to a patient with early RA is aggressive. Methotrexate is always the first 
DMARD that the patient is started on, and if an adequate response is not observed within 3-6 
months, a step up in therapy is made by adding on drugs. For assessment of progression, composite indices like Disease Activity Score - 28 (DAS-28) can 
used. Other options: Option A: Changing the route of administration of methotrexate from oral to parenteral is not a 
part of step up Option C: Priority is given to minimising the duration the patient is on steroids. Option D: Anti -TNF agents (adalimumab, etanercept) are not recommended as a monotherapy, 
and are reserved for treatment in combination with DMARDs. This is due to the fact that the 
efficacy of monotherapy is lesser than that of DMARDs, and the adverse effects include increased 
risk of serious infections, re-activation of latent TB and opportunistic fungal infections. They are 
reserved for cases where there is a lack of response with the first line agents.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following is a Janus kinase inhibitor used in patients with rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.explanation:
The Janus kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is tofacitinib. Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are Janus kinase inhibitors used as monotherapy or 
combination therapy in rheumatoid arthritis. 570 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Anakinra is an IL-1 antagonist. Option B: Tocilizumab is an IL-6 antagonist. Option C: Abatacept acts by inhibiting co-stimulation of T cells.

questions.question:
Question 18: A 28-year-old pregnant lady visits your OPD with complaints of painful swelling of her hands 
since past 2 months. Investigations reveal positive rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP 
antibodies. Which of the following DMARDs should not be prescribed to her?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis (RA). Leflunomide should not be 
prescribed in pregnancy as it is a category X drug. DMARDs classified as Category X in pregnancy (contraindicated in pregnancy) are: • Methotrexate • Leflunomide

questions.question:
Question 19: What is the isotype of the rheumatoid factor most commonly measured in the laboratory? 563 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
IgM isotype is the rheumatoid factor (RF) most commonly measured in laboratories. IgM RF has been found in 75–80% of patients with rheumatoid arthritis. IgG and IgA isotypes of 
RF have also been identified. However, RF is not specific for rheumatoid arthritis and can also be found in the following 
conditions: • Primary Sjögren’s syndrome • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Subacute bacterial endocarditis • Hepatitis B and C

questions.question: Question 20: Iritis is seen in all except:
questions.explanation:
Iritis is seen in all the above conditions except rheumatoid arthritis. Iritis or iridocyclitis is also known as anterior uveitis. Anterior uveitis is seen in: • Ankylosing spondylitis • Juvenile rheumatoid arthritis • Psoriasis • Reactive arthritis • Systemic lupus erythematosus • Leprosy 571 
Sold by @itachibot Posterior uveitis is seen in: • Vogt-Koyanagi Harada syndrome • Diseases like toxoplasmosis, cysticercosis, coccidioidomycosis, toxocariasis, histoplasmosis • Infections- Candida, Pneumocystis carinii, Cryptococcus, Aspergillus, and Cytomegalovirus • Cat-scratch disease, Whipple’s disease, and brucellosis Both anterior and posterior uveitis is seen in: • Sarcoidosis • Behcet's disease • Inflammatory bowel disease • Herpes infections, Syphilis, Lyme disease, TB, onchocerciasis Intermediate uveitis/pars planitis is seen in multiple sclerosis. 572 
Sold by @itachibot Asthma & COPD
